title: RL31320
content: The Library Services and Technology Act (LSTA) was reauthorized under the Museum and Library Services Act of 2003, with funding allocated for library services and technology grants to states. Funding is distributed through formula grants to state library administrative agencies for expanding services and access to learning. The Library Services and Technology Act (LSTA) provides funding for expanding library services and access to information, targeting under served populations. A percentage of funds is reserved for national activities, Native Americans, and federal administration, with 3.75% allocated for national activities such as research, demonstrations, and education for librarians. The Library Services and Technology Act (LSTA) allocates funding for expanding library services and access to information, with specific percentages reserved for national activities, Native Americans, and federal administration. Each state receives a flat grant of $340,000, with the federal share of costs set at 66%. States must maintain spending levels for library programs to avoid reductions in LSTA grants. The Library Services and Technology Act (LSTA) provides funding for library programs, with minimum state allotments set at $680,000. Outlying areas receive a minimum of $60,000 if appropriations allow. Participating states must develop five-year plans to enhance information-sharing. The Library Services and Technology Act (LSTA) provides funding for library programs, with minimum state allotments set at $680,000. Participating states must develop five-year plans to enhance information-sharing networks and target library services to disadvantaged populations. A wide variety of libraries may receive LST aid, not just public and research libraries. No more than 4% of each state's grant may be used for administration. LST funds are intended to provide states with considerable flexibility in fund usage. The Library Services and Technology Act (LSTA) provides funding for library programs, with states having flexibility in fund usage. The Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS) administers LST funds competitively within states. The IMLS is an independent agency under the National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities, with the current director being Robert Martin. The Office of Library Services within the IMLS is overseen by a Deputy Director with a library science degree. Funding for Library Services and Technology (LST) has increased from $210.597 million in FY2006 to $220.855 million in FY2007. Initiatives since FY2003 have focused on training and recruiting librarians, providing scholarships, and enhancing diversity in the field. The federal government has provided direct aid for public libraries since the Library Services and Construction Act (LSCA) in 1956. The Library Services and Technology Act consolidated and replaced various programs under the L-HHS-ED Appropriations Act of 1997. The Library Services and Technology Act (LSTA) was reauthorized as Title II, Library Services and Technology (LST), of the Museum and Library Services Act of 2003 (MLSA). State discretion in selecting grantees and fund usage has increased under the current LST program, with a focus on library services and technology provisions. Construction aid under the former LSCA Title II is not authorized for LST grants, as explicitly stated in P.L. 108-81. The Museum and Library Services Act of 2003 (P.L. 108-81) reauthorized the Library Services and Technology Act (LSTA) as Title II, focusing on new forms of information sharing like the Internet. Changes included prohibiting funding for projects deemed obscene and defining "obscene." The Director of the IMLS was required to establish procedural standards for reviewing projects. The Museum and Library Services Act of 2003 (P.L. 108-81) reauthorized the Library Services and Technology Act (LSTA) with new provisions such as prohibiting funding for projects deemed obscene and setting procedural standards for project review. It also increased minimum state allotments for library services and outlying areas, authorized specific funding amounts for Library Services and Museum Services for FY2004, and allocated advisory functions previously delegated to the National. The Museum and Library Services Act of 2003 reauthorized Library Services and Technology Act with new provisions, including locating advisory functions within a new National Museum and Library Services Board, increasing federal administrative costs to fund this new function, and permitting the Director of the IMLS to make national awards for library service. H.R. 13 (Hoekstra) was introduced to reauthorize Library Services and Technology within the Museum and Library Services Act of 2003. The Museum and Library Services Act of 2003, introduced on January 7, 2003, was passed by the House on March 6, 2003. H.R. 13 changed authorization for Library Services and Museum Services funding. It included new provisions for grant evaluation and prohibited funding for projects deemed obscene. The Director was required to analyze the impact of museum and library services. The Museum and Library Services Act of 2003, passed by the House on March 6, 2003, would have increased funding for federal administrative costs and established a new National Museum and Library Services Board within the IMLS. It allowed the Director to make national awards for library service and increased minimum state allotments for Library Services. The Senate incorporated S. 888 into H.R. 13, passing it with reduced authorization levels for FY2004. The bill included provisions for increased state allotments and funding for Library and Museum Services. The Senate introduced S. 238, which included provisions related to Library Services and Technology, Museum Services, and amendments raising liability amounts in the Arts and Artifacts Indemnity Act. The bill was referred to the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions.
